content: Poverty rates have been rising since 2000, with only three significant declines between 2000 and 2015. Policymakers are reexamining the drivers of poverty and the effectiveness of policy responses. A diverse group of families and individuals are in poverty, with a focus on the role of work in their lives. The data shows that people in poverty are a diverse group, with a focus on the role of work in their lives. Factors like income from work, living arrangements, and other family well-being aspects influence individuals' experiences of poverty. This snapshot examines the composition of people in poverty, rather than other factors affecting family well-being. This snapshot focuses on the composition of people in poverty, looking at what groups make up the poverty population. It highlights how different demographic groups may have varying poverty rates and shares in the overall poverty population. For a more in-depth analysis of poverty rates among different groups and trends over time, readers are referred to CRS Report R44644. Poverty is a lack of resources to meet basic needs, with the official measure used by the U.S. Census Bureau being family-based. An individual's poverty status is determined by their money income compared to a dollar threshold based on family composition. The poverty status of an individual is determined by comparing their income to a dollar threshold based on family composition. The official poverty measure has limitations, such as only considering pre-tax money income and not accounting for government taxes and non-cash benefits. It also does not take assets into account, but recent changes now consider distributions from retirement savings as income. The official poverty measure looks at pre-tax money income and does not consider government taxes and non-cash benefits. It also does not include the value of assets, but recent changes now count distributions from retirement savings as income. The measure is uniform across the country and does not adjust for differences in living costs in different areas. The current definition of family does not account for modern resource-sharing arrangements like cohabiting couples. The Census Bureau has a supplemental poverty measure that considers taxes, transfers, housing costs, and uses an expanded family definition. Children accounted for one-third of all people in poverty in America in 2015, despite making up less than a quarter of the total population. Children in America are disproportionately poor, with a poverty rate of 19.7% in 2015. They rely on adult caretakers for support, often from earnings. Over 90% of children lived in families with at least one adult earner, and 50.3% lived in families with two or more adult workers. Among children in the total population, over 90% lived in families with at least one adult earner, and 50.3% lived in families with two or more adult earners. Two-thirds of poor children lived in families with one or more earners, with 57.5% in families with one earner and 10.5% in families with two or more earners. The distribution of children who were poor in 2015 showed that 54.1% lived in female-headed families. In 2015, children in female-headed families made up the majority of those living in poverty, while children in married couple families accounted for one-third. Despite a low poverty rate for children in married couple families, the large population size meant a significant number of poor children lived in this family type. Among working-age adults who were poor, the majority did not have earnings from work, with only 38.8% working in some capacity. A small share (10.4%) worked full-time all year. When asked why they were not working, a wide range of reasons were given. In 2015, a majority of working-age adults in poverty were employed in some capacity, with only a small percentage working full-time all year. Reasons for not working included illness, caregiving, education, retirement, and job availability. Educational attainment was linked to success in the workforce, with higher credentials leading to higher earnings and more stable employment. Credentials indicating higher levels of education correlate with higher earnings and job stability. In 2015, the largest group of poor working-age adults had a high school diploma but no post-secondary credential. Even among those aged 25 to 64, high school graduates without further education remained the largest group among the poor. Family living arrangements are more prevalent in the overall population than among the poor. 41% of all working-age adults in poverty lived outside of a family, including those living alone, with cohabiting partners, or other unrelated adults/roommates. The poverty status of individuals living with others is based on each individual's income, with no pooling of income assumed in the official poverty measure. In 2015, aged adults accounted for 14.9% of the total population but only 9.7% of the population in poverty. The poverty rate among aged adults was 8.8% in 2015. Income from work plays a key role in determining the economic well-being of aged adults, with 77.0% of adults aged 65 and older not working in 2015. Income from work is crucial for the economic well-being of aged adults. Social Security, pensions, and other benefits earned from past work are common sources of income for aged individuals. However, a smaller percentage of aged adults in poverty receive these benefits compared to the overall aged population. In 2015, retirement, disability, or survivor pensions were received by the families of 48.5% of all aged persons, but only 7.7% of families of aged persons in poverty received these benefits. Earnings from current work were received by 40.7% of aged persons' families, with only 11.0% of families of aged persons in poverty receiving work-derived income. Most aged adults in the total population lived in families with income from work, either past work or current work, with a smaller percentage among aged persons in poverty. In 2015, almost three in four aged adults lived in families with income from work, including past work or current work. A significant portion of aged adults in poverty lived alone, with a lower likelihood of living in families compared to the overall aged population. Income from work plays a central role in determining poverty status, with children relying on family members' work, working-age adults on their own work, and aged adults on past work or the work of those they live with. However, sometimes earnings from work are insufficient to prevent poverty.
